## For not-so-large sample
```{r, echo=FALSE}
sliderInput("n", label = "Number of observations:", min = 1, max = 1000, value = 1, step = 1)

renderPlot(hist(
  rbinom(input$n, 1, 0.5),
  breaks = 10,
  main = paste(
    "Binomial distribution with",
    input$n,
    "observation(s).",
    "Sample mean =",
    round(mean(rbinom(input$n, 1, 0.5)), digits = 5)
  ), xlab = ""
))

renderPlot(hist(
  rnorm(input$n),
  main = paste(
    "Standard normal distribution with",
    input$n,
    "observation(s).",
    "Sample mean =",
    round(mean(rnorm(input$n)), digits = 5)
  ), xlab = ""
))
```

## For large(r) sample
```{r, echo=FALSE}
sliderInput("n", label = "Number of observations:", min = 1, max = 1000000, value = 1, step = 1)

renderPlot(hist(
  rbinom(input$n, 1, 0.5),
  breaks = 10,
  main = paste(
    "Binomial distribution with",
    input$n,
    "observation(s).",
    "Sample mean =",
    round(mean(rbinom(input$n, 1, 0.5)), digits = 5)
  ), xlab = ""
))

renderPlot(hist(
  rnorm(input$n),
  main = paste(
    "Standard normal distribution with",
    input$n,
    "observation(s).",
    "Sample mean =",
    round(mean(rnorm(input$n)), digits = 5)
  ), xlab = ""
))
```
Notice that sample mean gets closer and closer to the population mean when the number of observation increases, but it will *never* be strictly equal.
